content: There are dozens of TeX editors so far, such as Texpad and WinEdt. After encountered some wired bugs on Texpad, I decided to use native TeX Live / MacTex. However, TexShop (on macOS) does not have a pretty highlight system. It seems that the Visual Studio Code is one of the beast choice.
title: A Fast Guide on Writing LaTeX with LaTeX Workshop in VS Code

content: Step 1. Download & Install TeX LiveWindows users: download texlive.iso here. Mac users: download MacTeX.pkg here. Here are some references for the installation: TeX Live on Windows Installing MacTeX For Windows users, after installation, you should add TeX Live executables to your system PATH.
title: A Fast Guide on Writing LaTeX with LaTeX Workshop in VS Code

content: Step 2. Download & Install Visual Studio CodeYou can download it here. The installation is easy.
title: A Fast Guide on Writing LaTeX with LaTeX Workshop in VS Code

content: Step 3. Install & Config LaTeX WorkshopFollows the screenshot below to install the extension LaTeX Workshop. install-extension After doing that, you may press Shift + Ctrl + P (Windows) or Shift + cmd + P (macOS) to show all commands. Then type Open Settings JSON and open the first item (as shown below). open-json Now copy and paste the following to your json file (inside the brackets {}). "latex-workshop.latex.tools": [ { "name": "latexmk", "command": "latexmk", "args": [ "-synctex=1", "-interaction=nonstopmode", "-file-line-error", "-pdf", "-outdir=%OUTDIR%", "%DOC%" ], "env": {} }, { "name": "xelatex", "command": "xelatex", "args": [ "-synctex=1", "-interaction=nonstopmode", "-file-line-error", "%DOC%" ], "env": {} }, { "name": "pdflatex", "command": "pdflatex", "args": [ "-synctex=1", "-interaction=nonstopmode", "-file-line-error", "%DOC%" ], "env": {} }, { "name": "bibtex", "command": "bibtex", "args": [ "%DOCFILE%" ], "env": {} } ], "latex-workshop.latex.recipes": [ { "name": "pdfLaTeX", "tools": [ "pdflatex" ] }, { "name": "latexmk üîÉ", "tools": [ "latexmk" ] }, { "name": "xelatex", "tools": [ "xelatex" ] }, { "name": "pdflatex ‚ûû bibtex ‚ûû pdflatex`√ó2", "tools": [ "pdflatex", "bibtex", "pdflatex", "pdflatex" ] }, { "name": "xelatex ‚ûû bibtex ‚ûû xelatex`√ó2", "tools": [ "xelatex", "bibtex", "xelatex", "xelatex" ] } ]

content: Step 4. Write & CompileNow you may open a tex file or create a new one. If you want to compile the file, press Ctrl + Alt + B (Windows) or option + cmd + B (macOS). Moreover, you may choose another recipes from the sidebar. There is button in the right top corner to preview PDF file. tex-recipes
